awd_titl_txt: High-Dimensional Interaction Detection and Nonparametric Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how variables interact with each other is fundamentally important in many scientific discoveries and contemporary applications, especially in areas such as social networks, marketing, medicine, genetics, and cancer studies. Identifying important interactions can also help improve model interpretability and prediction. Yet interaction detection with high-dimensional data poses great challenges since the number of pairwise interactions increases quadratically with the number of covariates and that of higher-order interactions grows even faster. Although there is a growing literature on interaction detection, there is a limited amount of work on the error rate control and inference aspects. Building robust statistical foundations of interaction detection and nonparametric inference, and offering reproducible and scalable algorithms for selecting important interactions can greatly facilitate the use of these much-needed tools in real applications. The common theme underlying this entire project is that of developing statistical methodologies and theories on high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference with statistical guarantees and improved reproducibility and interpretability.


This project has three interrelated aims of timely theoretical and methodological studies on high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference. The first aim establishes the theoretical foundation of prediction and false sign rate control for interaction detection in ultra-high dimensional regression models. The second aim builds on the recent development of model-X knockoffs and proposes new methods for high-dimensional interaction detection with false discovery rate control and appealing power. The third aim further investigates the nonlinear interactions between a pair of high-dimensional random vectors and develops a new testing procedure for high-dimensional nonparametric inference through the lens of distance correlation. The systematic research program developed in three aims above will help build rigorous statistical foundations of theory and methodologies for high-dimensional data analysis that can guide practitioners and researchers. The investigators also plan to systematically develop tractable and efficient computation algorithms to implement the proposed methods through free software packages, like R and Python, and then make them readily available and publicize them in all relevant fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The systematic research program and new findings developed in the three aims of the project can help build rigorous statistical foundations of theory and methodologies for high-dimensional data analysis and data science that can guide practitioners and researchers on high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference with statistical guarantees and improved reproducibility and interpretability. In particular, through ten specific research projects that are related to Aims 1-3 of the proposal, jointly with his collaborators the PI has developed new high-dimensional learning and inference methods for a range of data science applications. For example, the TDNN algorithm was developed for optimal nonparametric inference with two-scale distributional nearest neighbors, the SIMPLE algorithm was developed for statistical inference on membership profiles in large networks, the DeepLINK algorithm was developed for deep learning inference using knockoffs with applications to genomics, the NSL algorithm was developed for nonsparse learning with latent variables, the HID algorithm was developed for high-dimensional interaction detection with false sign rate control, and the HGBICp method was developed for large-scale model selection in misspecified generalized linear models. Moreover, novel asymptotic theoretical results were established for the eigenvectors for large random matrices with diverging spikes, high-dimensional random forests, and high-dimensional distance correlation inference with important real applications. This project has involved the training of a number of Ph.D. students, postdoctoral scholars, and undergraduates, with several joining the academia. The PI also gave many invited talks at various seminars and conferences on these new research findings. Overall, the new statistical methods and tools developed in the three aims of the project can be broadly applicable to contemporary applications of high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference in many areas such as social networks, marketing, medicine, genetics, and cancer studies, with improved model interpretability, reproducibility, and prediction.


Last Modified: 10/24/2023
Modified by: Jinchi Lv
